sen.e: Events that occurred at or right after the end of the Kamakura period such as the Genko War and the Kemmu Restoration are usually considered part of the Nanbokucho period, but strictly speaking, the term refers only to the span of time between 1336 (Engen 1/Kemmu 3), when Takauji ASHIKAGA raised Emperor Komyo to the Chrysanthemum throne, thus leading to a schism in the Imperial Court after Emperor Go-Daigo departed Kyoto and established his Court at Yoshino, and 1392 (Genchu 9/Meitoku 3) when the two courts were again unified; it overlaps with the early Muromachi period.
